## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
0625/61  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 326, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2023  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[855, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 636]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 737, 89]]<|/det|> A student determines the weight of a metre ruler using a balancing method. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 334, 120]]<|/det|> Fig. 1.1 shows the set-up. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[101, 128, 897, 237]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 255, 532, 274]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 285, 146, 304]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 285, 920, 335]]<|/det|> The student places the metre ruler on the pivot. She places a load P on the metre ruler at the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark. She adjusts the position of the metre ruler on the pivot so that the metre ruler is as near as possible to being balanced. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 348, 598, 367]]<|/det|> The ruler balances with the pivot at the \(75.0 \text{cm}\) mark. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 380, 645, 397]]<|/det|> Calculate the distance \(a\) from the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark to the pivot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 425, 562, 443]]<|/det|> Record the value of \(a\) in the first row of Table 1.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 425, 920, 443]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 456, 146, 475]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 456, 903, 473]]<|/det|> She records, in Table 1.1, the distance \(b\) from the pivot to the \(0.0 \text{cm}\) end of the metre ruler. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 486, 920, 520]]<|/det|> She repeats the procedure placing the load P at the \(85.0 \text{cm}\) mark, \(80.0 \text{cm}\) mark, \(75.0 \text{cm}\) mark and \(70.0 \text{cm}\) mark. She records the values of \(a\) and \(b\) in Table 1.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 534, 541, 551]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 564, 636, 711]]<|/det|>
\(a/\text{cm}\)\(b/\text{cm}\)
75.0
13.171.9
11.368.8
9.465.6
7.562.5

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(a / \text{cm}\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(b / \text{cm}\) (\(x\)-axis). Start the \(y\)-axis at \(a = 0.0 \text{cm}\). Start the \(x\)-axis at a suitable value for the results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 295, 134]]<|/det|>
Draw the best-fit line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 698, 912, 715]]<|/det|>
He moves the screen slowly until a clearly focused image is formed on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 712, 920, 745]]<|/det|>

<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 912, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the time taken for water to evaporate to dryness when heated from above.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 633, 120]]<|/det|>
Fig. 4.1 shows the set-up. The power of the heater is constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 371, 151]]<|/det|>
The following is also available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 166, 138, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 165, 457, 183]]<|/det|>
supply of water at room temperature

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 181, 253, 197]]<|/det|>
• metre ruler.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[168, 203, 828, 343]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 355, 532, 374]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 387, 918, 405]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how **one** factor affects the time taken for the water to evaporate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 418, 536, 437]]<|/det|>
You do **not** need to write about safety precautions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 450, 218, 467]]<|/det|>
You should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 482, 485, 499]]<|/det|>
• state any additional apparatus required

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 497, 567, 515]]<|/det|>
• explain briefly how you would do the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 513, 591, 530]]<|/det|>
• state the key variables that you would keep constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 528, 918, 561]]<|/det|>
• draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 559, 683, 576]]<|/det|>
• explain how you would use your readings to reach a conclusion.
